meanings.definition: To question or challenge someone, especially in a formal setting.
meanings.sent1: During the trial, the lawyer will interpellate the witness to get more information.
meanings.sent2: Please do not interpellate the speaker while they are giving a presentation.
meanings.sent3: The detective decided to interpellate the suspect in a playful manner to see their reaction.
meanings.sent4: Her piercing gaze seemed to interpellate the truth out of him.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's stern look was enough to interpellate the students into confessing.

meanings.definition: To interrupt or disrupt a conversation or event.
meanings.sent1: The loud noise from outside interpellated our discussion.
meanings.sent2: Try not to interpellate when others are speaking.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected phone call interpellated our peaceful dinner.
meanings.sent4: The sudden rain interpellated the outdoor party, forcing everyone inside.
meanings.sent5: The barking dog interpellated the quiet of the night.

meanings.definition: To call upon or summon someone to answer a question or provide information.
meanings.sent1: The teacher will interpellate the students to see if they understood the lesson.
meanings.sent2: The committee may interpellate the witness for further clarification.
meanings.sent3: The magician interpellated the audience to participate in his trick.
meanings.sent4: The judge's decision to interpellate the expert witness surprised everyone in the courtroom.
meanings.sent5: The journalist will interpellate the politician during the press conference.
